2d:
A question I am frequently asked is, "How can I understand the needs of my customers?"

Let me share a few tactics I use to gather data to assess needs:

🔍 Customer feedback loops: Collect feedback through surveys, customer interviews or panels, social media, online reviews etc. etc. Regularly review customer needs and concerns holistically.

🔍 Data: Focus on quality and variety of data from products and channels. Consider how you can identify behaviours, preferences or choices at different stages of the journey. Don’t overthink the data (I see this a lot!). If the data you want isn’t available, what is? Just start.

🔍 Try it yourself: Experience your product or service personally. Listen to customer calls and engage with online self-help, loyalty programs or community sites. Identify pain points and gain empathy from standing in your customers shoes!

🔍 Observation: Step outside your office and away from the spreadsheet… Go meet a customer, observe their environment and how they work. What tools and process can you see them using, what type of language are you hearing, what energy can you feel in the room? You are one of many things they care about so understand where you fit in their day to day and soak it all up.

While data and analytics provide valuable insights, it's important to remember that they don't always capture the full picture. Real-life contradictions can arise… I think we all agree that humans will do one thing, and say another, so dont let it catch you out!

How do you approach customer need identification? Share your top tips below 👇

On the back of Mick de Brenni's announcements of extra financial assistance to make electric vehicles more affordable for Queenslanders, you can find recent Energex research on EVs here...


EV charging is a very flexible load for management – either by owners themselves or others. Owners are open to options as to how to manage their EV charging for their benefit; accessing advantageous pricing during the day, using the solar generation they may have in their home, use of their own active control mechanisms or having others manage the charging on their behalf.

This research illustrated customer charging behaviour that was both reasonable (based on access to retail tariffs and behind-the-meter generation) and responsive (able to be changed without a negative impact). This is also useful for networks. However, there is room for greater benefit for owners and networks through promotion of flexible EV charging options that minimise convenience charging at peak times and maximise daytime charging using renewable energy generation.

Reach out if you would like to know more.

And how do you spark a data-driven culture within the business teams?

In this episode, Michaela will share her insights on bringing all teams together to drive success and collaboration.

is the Head of Data Strategy and Engagement at . They are one of Australia's biggest banks, with more than 7,000 employees helping over 1.9 million customers achieve their financial goals. Bendigo’s vision is to be Australia's bank of choice, and they believe their success is driven by their purpose – to feed into the prosperity of our customers and communities, not off it.

Michaela is dedicated to helping organisations not only survive but thrive in the face of digital disruption by utilising data, AI, and technology. Prior to her current role at Bendigo, Michaela served as the Senior Manager of Data Governance at RSL Queensland.

In this exclusive analytics podcast episode, Michaela shares:

- Her current role as the Head of Data Strategy and Engagement at Bendigo and Adelaide Bank

It’s Day 1 of the Love + Work Interview Series, and we’ve got nearly 600 women plugging in for a topic most women don’t talk about nearly enough!

"𝗡𝗼 𝗠𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 - 𝗶𝗻 𝗟𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸"

Today’s conversation will jolt you from the trance of a mediocre, routine, and possibly passionless relationship – 𝘦𝘷𝘦𝘯 𝘰𝘯𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘭𝘰𝘰𝘬𝘴 𝘴𝘶𝘤𝘤𝘦𝘴𝘴𝘧𝘶𝘭 𝘰𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘰𝘶𝘵𝘴𝘪𝘥𝘦 – and awaken you to the heightened level of vibrancy most modern women crave!

Hey GrowthHackerGPT, we did a webinar this morning for North America. It was well received. Thank you for the suggestion. Now, we've already started building the community in the Facebook group. Currently, we have about 400 audiences in the group. That's only 5% of our existing users.

Do you have any suggestions for increasing the number of community members?

🤖

Hello! I'm glad to hear that your webinar went well and that you've started building your community on Facebook. To increase the number of community members, consider implementing the following strategies:

1. Leverage existing users: Send an email or in-app notification to your existing users, highlighting the benefits of joining the Facebook group. Offer exclusive content, special offers, or early access to new features as incentives.

2. Promote on social media: Regularly promote your Facebook group on your company's social media channels, including Twitter, LinkedIn, and Instagram. Share engaging content from the group to attract new members.

3. Cross-promotion: Collaborate with complementary businesses, influencers, or industry thought leaders to promote each other's communities. This can expand your reach and attract new members.

4. Webinar follow-up: After each webinar, send a follow-up email to the attendees, thanking them for their participation and inviting them to join the Facebook group for further discussions and exclusive content.

5. Add a call-to-action on your website: Place a prominent call-to-action (CTA) on your website, inviting visitors to join the Facebook group. Make sure to highlight the benefits of joining the community.

6. Run Facebook ads: Target your existing users and potential customers with Facebook ads to promote the group. Make sure to refine your target audience and craft a compelling ad copy to attract new members.

7. Engage existing members: Encourage current group members to invite their friends and colleagues who may benefit from the community. You can also create a referral program, offering incentives to those who bring new members to the group.

8. Create valuable content: Ensure that your Facebook group offers valuable, exclusive content that is not available elsewhere. This will incentivize users to join and participate actively in the community.

9. Host exclusive events: Organize online events, such as Q&A sessions, guest interviews, or workshops, exclusively for the Facebook group members. Promote these events across your channels to attract new members.

10. Monitor and optimize: Regularly analyze the growth and engagement of your Facebook group. Adjust your strategies based on the performance and feedback from your community members.

🧞‍♂️: "Your wish is my command! (poof) Congratulations, you now have a 10-room dollhouse, a toy car that goes 200 mph, and a blonde poodle named Curvy."

👨: "What?! This isn't what I wanted! What I need is a real mansion, a real Ferrari that can go 200 mph, and a real human partner who's beautiful, kind, and loves me for who I am!"

🧞‍♂️: "Ah, my apologies. It seems my programming may misinterpret vague requests. You ought to offer more details to ensure accuracy!"

An AI is a lot like the Genie in this story. Precision matters.

Poorly written prompts could backfire.

Well-written ones can lead to incredible results.

Prompt engineers are like the super creators of the AI world.

They have the power to shape and mould AI with their words.

They understand AI's weaknesses, craft unique inputs that lead to incredibly accurate results, and train it to its fullest potential. I'm stating the obvious here — but they also make good money doing it.

"Why should I hone this skill if I'm not a prompt engineer in the first place?" you ask.

With generative AI like ChatGPT being such a hot commodity at the moment, it's a skill that can grant you headway in the tech industry. As AI becomes increasingly influential in how we live and work, those who can write effective prompts will be the most sought-after talents.

So if you want to create something magical with AI, it’s time to brush up on those prompt-writing skills.

And where better to start than crafting custom prompts in Engage AI?

Challenge yourself to make prompts that can create meaningful, contextually relevant comments in the tone, voice, and sentiment that you want.

Let Engage AI be the communication magic, and you the master of its power.

Is it possible to create ethical AI that truly incorporates ethnic diversity?

And is it possible to avoid creating AI that doesn’t embed bias and perpetuate stereotypes?

And…do we want to?

From having worked on the ethics behind lethal autonomous weapons in the past, Emmanuel is here to discuss the ethics behind AI.

is the Co-Director & Co-Founder of the . The Global AI Ethics Institute (GAIEI) aims at opening the debate on AI ethics to all philosophical stances, wisdoms and perspectives coming from all cultures. It is a global think tank built as a hub for researchers, thinkers and practitioners working in the field of AI ethics all around the world.

Besides his work with GAIEI, Emmanuel is a Research Fellow with the Society and Technology Study Center CEST POLI USP, a Lecturer at the IA Institut, a Professor at Collège La Cité, and an Instructor at the Vectors Institute. Emmanuel served in the French Air Force for 27 years. After having worked on military ethics - more precisely on ethics applied to Lethal autonomous weapons - his focus turned to the ethics applied to Artificial intelligence.

In this exclusive analytics podcast episode, Emmanuel shares:

- His current role as the Co-Director & Co-Founder of the Global AI Ethics Institute

- Whether or not it's possible to create ethical AI with ethnic diversity

- How to avoid embedding bias into AI

- The challenges that arise when trying to create diverse AI ethics boards

- The most pressing ethical issues facing AI today

- How the lack of diversity in the field of AI development can lead to biassed algorithms and decision making

- Including less advanced societies in AI ethics and diversity

- Avoiding situations similar to how AI image-generators are perpetuating stereotypes

- His advice for organisations starting to think about the ethical implications of their AI systems and promoting diversity in the field

Are you afraid of bees?

How would your opinion change if bees were robots?

RoboBees!

But this is no joke.

Inspired by the biology of bees, researchers at the Wyss Institute are developing what they call RoboBees.

RoboBees are tiny AI-powered robots - half the size of a paper clip - that could take on important roles in agriculture or disaster relief in the future.

Some of them can swim, fly, and perch on surfaces using static electricity.

They fly on their own with a compact power source.

And they use smart sensors that mimic the eyes and antennae of a bee to respond to the environment.

They even coordinate among each other, creating an effective unit just like a colony.

They've been in development for over a decade now but we could potentially be looking at a future with artificial pollination in emergencies.

The Colony Collapse Disorder is the phenomenon of a dramatic worldwide reduction in honeybees.

This is a threat to the crops that depend on pollination from bees that are collecting nectar to make honey.

And these crops are about a third of the food we farm.

No bees means no pollination means no food.

But what do you think?

Are you buzzing with excitement for these tiny AI buzzers, or are we flying in the wrong direction when it comes to bees?

ChatGPT by the Elon Musk co-founded OpenAI is a new AI tool designed to help people communicate with computers in a more natural and intuitive way using natural language processing technology.

Since being released on the 30th of November, a week ago exactly, it has garnered over 1 million users!

Academics have generated responses to exam questions that would result in full marks if submitted by a student and programmers have used the tool to solve coding challenges in any programming language of their choosing in a matter of seconds.

So, I decided to test it out to share with all of you.

(𝘍𝘪𝘯𝘥 𝘢𝘭𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘱𝘰𝘯𝘴𝘦𝘴 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘴𝘭𝘪𝘥𝘦𝘴𝘩𝘰𝘸 𝘣𝘦𝘭𝘰𝘸)

I started by chatting with it - asking it about itself and then moving on to other technology-related questions.

I also tried having more fun with it, asking for fun facts, a joke, and a funny story.

The fun fact was fascinating. The joke was fine. The story was 𝘲𝘶𝘢𝘤𝘬𝘦𝘳𝘴!

It pretty strictly rejected my own attempt at joking around with it myself.

Maybe knock-knock jokes are old hat.

Its answers were all very lengthy but they read well without any grammatical errors and sounded genuine, like a human could have written them.

It even wrote me a short essay when prompted.

One of the most hyped aspects of ChatGPT is its ability to write code and find errors in existing code.

I attempted to get it to write code for automatically removing background noise from an audio clip, specifically in the Python programming language.

Whether or not the code works, I haven’t tested.

It should be noted that Stack Overflow has temporarily banned users from sharing answers to coding queries generated by the chatbot due to some of the generated codes being incorrect while outwardly appearing fine.

Lastly, I asked it to write the concluding sentence for this post - but in a Shakespearean style.

So, let’s end it with that.

In sooth, ChatGPT doth prove a most wondrous tool for unlocking the mysteries of natural language processing, and its capabilities do attest to the boundless potential of artificial intelligence.

Let me know your thoughts on ChatGPT in the comments below.
 
And what would you use it for?

“A computer program is said to learn from experience E with respect to some task T and some performance measure P, if its performance on T, as measured by P, improves with experience E."

And did you know it’s powered by Natural Language Processing (NLP)?

Recently, we built a project to rate a company's culture based on employees' reviews on a job site.

For this, we used a trained model that utilised NLP.

Since culture is often subjective, we first developed the benchmark and guideline.

We then used these labelled dataset to train the NLP model.

We also collected a list of keywords that could help the NLP model determine if a particular review is more good than bad and vice versa.

We could then rate all the companies in this world at scale through this ML application.

So, that’s one of the many examples of how you can use NLP.

Can AI-generated images be considered art?

Remember the last couple of times I talked about DALL·E 2?

Just in case you missed it, DALL·E is a new AI system that creates realistic images from a description in natural language.

But it isn’t the only AI image-generator out there making waves. 
Midjourney is a generative AI art tool that was available in Beta Mode for 24 hours earlier this month.

Now, it has just opened Beta Mode to anyone and everyone wanting to give it a shot.

Judging by the images it creates, Midjourney specialises in producing various art styles, including sci-fi and fantasy environments that will remind you of the concept art you’d see for video games.

The platform is Discord-based, so you’ll need to have a free account with the social network/instant messenger to use it but it’s well worth the time to create that account if you don’t have one yet.

It should be noted that you will have a limit of 25 free images, after which you’ll have to pay a monthly subscription.

So make those images count!

Find a link to the official website to start testing out the Beta in the comments.

Below is a stunning piece of ‘art’ generated by the AI - or would you just call it an ‘image’?

Tell me in the comments below - do you think AI-generated images can be considered real art, or does a human need to be behind the picture for it to count?

Either way, try out the Beta and share the generated image here on LinkedIn. Don’t forget to tag me so I can take a look!

is a podcast of business through the lens of data science hosted by me, founder of Data Driven Analytics. Together, we dive into learning and sharing where various industries are heading and how data and analytics is at the heart of shaping business growth and productivity.

TAS goes by an interview format. In every episode, I deliver a personalised interview for our guest of the week, a business leader using data analytics to drive growth. We release an episode every Monday and are based in Queensland, Australia (UTC+10).

TAS has been going strong for over 2 years now and we are looking to start mixing things up with a new voice.

𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗯𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗳𝗶𝘁 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗯𝗲𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺?

🎙️ Set yourself up as an industry leader

🎙️ Be seen and heard by our audience across the world on all of our platforms (podcast hosting platforms, LinkedIn, Youtube, Facebook, etc)

🎙️ Access to our podcast guest database

🎙️ An opportunity to network with other industry leaders that we interview

🎙️ A percentage of our sponsorship earnings (at the time of writing, we are rarely accepting sponsorships & receive no money for our episodes)

Is AI learning from the dark corners of the Internet?

Last week, I talked about DALL·E 2, a new AI system that can create realistic images and art from a description in natural language.
 
While the comments seemed intrigued by the AI, a few of you also mentioned that you were scared of it.

You’re not alone.

The video below discusses how we got to this point, how technology like DALL·E 2 works, and some of the implications it has on society and the Internet.

(Find the complications at minute 10:21)

Although the consequences of technology like this is unknown - as with technology that is now commonplace today - like other automated systems trained on historical data and internet images, it comes with risks that have not been resolved.

When AI learns from the Internet, it is also learning from the racist, sexist, and toxic traits of humans.

For example, recent studies showed that when tasked to put assorted images of human faces into a box, the AI:

- Identified women as a "homemaker" over white men

- Identified black men as "criminals" 10% more than white men

- Identified Latino men as "janitors" 10% more than white men

- Identified men as “doctors” more than women of all ethnicities

People are split on these AI’s. On one hand, it opens up a world of opportunities and accessibility. But are the potential negative effects worth it?

Tell me your thoughts in the comments. Yay or nay to technology like this?

Bonus video in the comments on its implications for human artists and more below.

Credit to Vox for the videos.

Creating new and original images from a few words alone is no longer a thing of sci-fi.

The image below was created only by inserting the term:

These simple but specific words generated this image with the mere push of a button.

DALL·E 2 is a new AI system that can create realistic images and art from a description in natural language.

Here’s a few other things it can do:

Practical Statistics for Data Scientists

Statistical methods are a key part of data science but few data scientists have formal statistics training. Courses and books on basic statistics rarely cover the topic from a data science perspective, while data science resources lack a deeper statistical perspective.

This resource is aimed at data scientists with some familiarity with the R programming language and some prior exposure to statistics. Both writers came to the world of data science from the world of statistics, creating this 562 page book with two goals;

1. to lay out, in digestible, navigable, and easily referenced form, key concepts from statistics that are relevant to data science

“Our data analytics is still in the dinosaur age. My GM hardly has any time to read the suggestions from our models.”

An old friend of mine called me up out of nowhere yesterday.

I immediately noticed how nervous he sounded on the other end.

For some context, we hadn’t spoken in a few years. There were no hard feelings. We both just got busy doing our own things and lost touch.

He’s been a data analytics professional for some time now, having picked it up a few years ago.

That’s why he was calling.

“I’m sure that’s not true,” I replied, still in the dark about what was going on but hoping to comfort him.

“Our competitors are leaving us in the dust. I know what it is. It’s our data projects. They aren’t working. They lead to nowhere, to nothing.”

“Well, do you have the data analytics embedded in the business or are they just sort of…floating around?”

“Embedded? What do you mean?”

Now, don’t get the wrong idea. My friend here is amazing at what he does.

This story isn’t to poke fun at him or mock him - more the opposite. I admire him for going out of his way to find help wherever he can and work towards improvement.

Besides, he isn’t alone in this.

According to Gartner, 85% of data analytics projects fail.

Worse yet, they predict that this trend will continue through 2022, with a high chance for success in only 1 out of 5 cases.

That’s why I created an assessment based on having successfully implemented over 30 analytics projects.

Through these experiences, I have shaped 18 critical questions with a scorecard that will assess your level of analytics maturity.

On completion, the fully customised report will provide greater clarity, insight, and advice to embed analytics.

If someone told you something like, “If you leave your house tomorrow, something bad will happen.”

What would you do?

You’d probably either be horribly confused, slightly offended, or maybe you’d even laugh, thinking it was all some big joke. Either way, you’re left with no explanation.

Why are people so obsessed with cryptocurrency? Isn’t it a little bit…suspicious? Maybe it’s a scam? It’s all downhill from here?

Well, cryptocurrency is very unique in many ways, and lots of people are attracted to that.

One unique thing about crypto is that it uses a public ledger.

So, what’s a public ledger? What does this mean for us and why does it make cryptocurrency so special in the first place?

A public ledger - in this case - is like a record-keeping system. It keeps the participants’ identities secure and anonymous, keeps their individual crypto balances, and also works as a record book of all genuine transactions that take place between network participants.

“But regular online banking has that too.”

Not quite in the same way.

With regular online banking, these transactions can only be verified by the participants, the bank, and other parties that may need to come in for whatever reason.

With cryptocurrency, the participants alone can verify these transactions, no one else. However, these transactions are maintained as a copy - a public ledger - that can be distributed to ensure all transactions are genuine and fair…all while keeping the participants anonymous.

Where it will go from here, who knows? Make sure you use genuine websites and networks to exchange it.

But if you’re still unsure…

From time to time, it’s helpful to get a look back at the basics!

Today’s topic --

What are the 7 key foundations of data governance?

1. Data needs to be aligned with business goals

The first principle. If your data governance efforts are not in line with your business outcomes, you are priming your data platform for failure,

2. Clearly laid out accountability among data users

Clear organization-wide perceptions about who is responsible for what part of the pipeline, analytics, and decision making will make faster communications and confident decisioning.

3. Trust-based governance

Not all information is equal. Data pipeline should also carry with it the trust score of each piece of data through effective use of metadata and data catalogues.

4. Transparency and Ethics

Principles of ethical operations and transparent decision-making should be embedded into your culture. Every decision should be clear, documented, and defensible.

5. Data risk management

Opportunities and risks should be considered hand in hand. Real-time risk assessment via a controlled environment and a robust information security framework enables you to fend off current risks and prepare you for future risks.

6. Upskilling

Without proper training and development, your employees won’t be able to perform in line with your data governance initiatives.

7. Data-driven culture

The upskilling efforts should also go hand in hand with your culture-building initiatives. The data-driven culture fosters cooperation, data storytelling, and innovation

How strong is your foundation?

You get the irony, right?

If you set out to find the data having the conclusion already in mind, you are most likely to get your biased view into the data and analytics.

Bias in data analytics results because of mainly 2 reasons:

Humans collecting the data are biased 
The data collected is biased

How do you save yourself and your business from biased data analytics?

The first step is knowing the types of common biases that often haunt business analytics:

- Confirmation bias -- When you start an analysis with a preconceived idea, hypothesis, or conclusion in mind.

- Outlier bias -- When just a few unusual data points screw up the whole calculation.

- Analytics bias -- When you are not factoring in all possible variables and comprehensive sets of data.

- Cognitive biases -- When you are imposing your subjective perception in sampling and data selection.

- Interpretation bias -- The way you are looking at things is not comprehensive leading to an incorrect conclusion.

- Prediction Bias -- Results of predictive analytics are skewed because of incomprehensive data sets or propagating the current state.

Information bias -- When you think certain information means something but actually it doesn’t mean what you think.

Some of the basics of data analytics that you should take care of to avoid biases are:

- Democratize data analytics in your organization 
- Use complete data sets factoring all variables
- Implement real-time analytics
- Be open to multiple outlooks and perspectives 
- Bring all the stakeholders into operations

Have you encountered any of these common analytics biases in business? If so, how did you notice the bias?

The image is hilarious. But most importantly, it gets a very pressing message across.

Although the case of sampling bias shown on the meme is very apparent, sampling bias can be very cheeky at times.

So, we should be super careful of sampling bias when it comes to working with data, especially survey data.

Sampling bias means selecting a collection of data that are not representative of the actual holistic diversity of the variable in question. 

It’s more evident in the case of surveys, however, any collection of data can be a victim of sampling bias, such as analysing only data from good sale periods to show better performance.

Sampling bias works in so many ways. What other ways can you cite from the top of your head?

Why and how should you be using data storytelling to find and explain business use cases?

Data and statistics are not just dry information.

Effective analysis of relevant data points tells us stories that can change the course of a business.

Here’s a story to explain the case of data storytelling.

Suppose a bank runs promotional campaigns to get more credit card accounts.

They train all their customer-facing employees to upsell credit cards and even announce commissions for each account gained.

Subsequently, their credit card accounts and users start to rise and the goals are met.

That’s a good example of nice banking.

But a few months down the line, the lending back office notices that a majority of the credit cards issued during that period are lying dormant. The bank is not getting any profits from those accounts.

Here comes the use case of constant data monitoring and analytics.

Now, the finance and business analyst of the bank has a great playing field to find the data points and explain to the management why they are leaving money on the table and how they can make the most use of the dormant credit cardholders.

With precise data storytelling, they can paint the picture of what’s going wrong and how to fix it.

- Why are the users not using the cards?

- Are they getting better service and offers from other banks?

- How much can the bank increase its earnings from the dormant accounts?

- How to offer better service and offers and inform the users about it?

- What roles can the customer-facing employees play in influencing the users?

There are many such questions to ask and things to consider to present the story!

An effective story with precise data analytics is sure to move the management into taking proper measures.

Do you know what the data hierarchy of needs is?

It’s an easy-to-use framework to evaluate at what stage of the data journey you are in and what else you need to move up to the next level of data efficiency.

Whenever you are evaluating a business or a project in terms of data capabilities, simply keep this framework in mind and you will be able to know where the business is and what it needs to advance. 

- As you can see in the image, the first stage of every data platform starts with the data itself. Do you have all the data collection processes and tools working in place?

- The second stage is creating the pipeline that will effectively move the data collected into storage for further preparation.

- Rightfully, at the third stage comes the actual cleaning and preparation of the data to facilitate segmentation, labelling, and analytics.

- You can easily guess that analytics can come only after the three basic stages have been fulfilled.

- The last two stages are the most advanced work with emerging technologies such as machine learning and artificial intelligence. 

How much strength does your organisation have at each of these stages?

We have been hearing some news about research being carried out on storing and retrieving digital data into DNA for a couple of years now.

But most recently, the research got a leg up.

Until now, the researchers found ways to store data into the DNA structure but no ways to retrieve the information back.

But now, researchers at MIT have found a way to retrieve data by encapsulating each data file into a 6-micrometre particle of silica.

Let’s not get into more science details here, and let’s take a look at the potential benefits this advanced technology can offer us. 

There are 10 trillion gigabytes of digital data in the world right now. On top of that, 2.5 million gigabytes of data are being created every day.

Storing and maintaining this gigantic amount of data requires a huge amount of space and resources. Each exabyte data centre takes the size of a football field and requires around $1 billion to build and maintain.

On the other hand, a coffee mug full of DNA could theoretically store all of the world’s data, according to Mark Bathe, an MIT professor of biological engineering.

Another cool thing about this is that once you make the DNA polymer, it doesn’t consume any energy. You can write the DNA and then store it forever.

Cool, isn’t it? 

Image credit: Wyss Institute

Data Analytics in Agriculture.

The world population is expected to reach more than nine billion by the year 2050, The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) predicts, we need a 70-per cent growth in agricultural production to meet the rising demand.

- Farming is a highly time-sensitive endeavour. The information about where and when to plant is essential for optimal production. When farmers get real-time data and information, they can figure out where and how to plant precisely at a granular level.

- For technologies like soil sensors, weather tracking, and GPS-enabled tractors, farmers are now getting unprecedented opportunities to maximise productivity. 

- Data analytics can help farmers tackle unpredictable weather, severe storms, drought and changing insect behaviours.

- Farmers now can monitor the growth and health of their crops in real-time, carry out predictive analytics to measure future yields and make resource management decisions based on historical data.

- They also gain real-time access to pricing data, which enables them to make profitable decisions. The right analytics offers them multifaceted insights at the customer level that they can utilize to gain maximum market share.

- The supply chain is also being revolutionised by the increasing use of data science. Apart from product tracing and timely demand monitoring, the communication among the retailers, distributors, and other stakeholders are getting seamless and effective.

These are the major use cases of data and analytics in farming from the top of my head.

It happens to the best of us.

When an idea of a promising project comes to mind, we feel very motivated & excited during the first few days. But slowly, the motivations start to fade away.

It is specifically true for long projects. Keeping up the morale & doing the hard work over a long period of time can be challenging.

So, what can we do to foster motivation for long-term projects?

Realistic & Strategic Planning

Nothing kills motivation faster than not getting desired results. That’s why we need a realistic project plan, acknowledging the fact that getting a favourable outcome can take months, if not years, to come.

Goal Setting

Break down the overall project plan into achievable sets of mini-goals. Each time we achieve a small goal, the motivation meter would get a chance to get higher up again.

Visualisation

Use a drawing or a picture that symbolises the end goal or why did you begin in the first place. Place it somewhere in your office. It will keep reminding you of your original zeal.

Delegate

Find out all the portions of the project that you can outsource or delegate to other experts. Of course, keeping the budget in mind.

The future of billboards is here!

Such 3D billboards and art installations have popped up recently and are making rounds in social media.

There are also some Augmented Reality (AR) billboards that are coming up.

In the case of the AR billboards, you can interact with the billboard using mobile devices.

There are currently two major types of augmented reality (AR) ads available:

- Marker-based

- Location-based

Marker-based AR ads require a marker (i.e. a target image) that customers can scan with their smartphone cameras to bring virtual content to life.

Location-based AR ads don’t require any markers (so there’s no need for a print image), as they project or overlay virtual content based on a user’s location (with the help of GPS).

Such innovations in advertising allow businesses to attract, impress and engage customers much more quickly and effectively along with adding the entertainment element into the ad campaigns.

For now, let’s enjoy this beautiful 3D billboard!

How to reduce the model updating & changing time by 20x?

You have 5 different analytics models running in the system, & whenever you need to change to a new model or update the percentage allocated to any particular model, you would have to make a request to your project manager to make the changes. The change request is then evaluated for its risks, & resources are allocated to make this change.

This takes 2 weeks to make a simple change.

Your customers are not going to wait for you in making those changes.

You don’t have to go through all of those processes & hassles if you design & drive your platform using data & tables.

Design & develop your platform to retrieve model allocation based on the data in a control table.

Whenever you want to update the model allocation, you will just have to update the data in the table.

Wouldn’t that be much more time saving for you & your teams?

Not only this will reduce the time by 20x to make the changes, but it will also reduce the dependency on your developers. Most importantly, it reduces the risks of making mistakes.

Do you remember the multiplication table that we all learned in school?

What if such tables never existed & we had to calculate 9*8 each time manually?

Math would have been much more difficult, wouldn’t it?

This is what precomputation does for analytics.

Analysing, calculating & evaluating all the frequently used numbers for faster & easier future use.

Precomputation enables:

- High concurrency & serving more consumers

- Maintaining query response times as data volumes keep growing

- Speeding up the process of data democratisation & the rise of citizen analysts

With the advent of big data, the use of precomputation has become much more pervasive.

As data volumes & the number of concurrent data users continue to increase, precomputation enables the cost & time to stay the same or even get lowered.

Although precomputed values would take up more space, the time it would save would compensate much more than that.

Also, with AI & auto ML technologies, the manual data preparation part of precomputation will keep getting automated.

How are you using the power of precomputation in your analytics platform?

The video is funny.

However, experiencing analysis paralysis in real life is not fun in any shape or size.

It’s so frustrating as if electrical currents of frustration and irritation are waving through your soul.

You have all the information, all the knowledge and yet you can’t make a decision.

That’s one of the dangers inherent in business analytics. If you deal with too much data, the dangers of information paralysis increase simultaneously.

So, what can we do?

Should we stop collecting all the data? Don’t try to look into anything and everything?

No!

- We have to still collect data. But we also have to know what to use and how to use them.

- We have to learn to differentiate between what’s useful for our purpose and what’s noise.

That’s where the value of real business knowledge and domain expertise comes to play along with the skills of business analytics.

Although we may not always feel the threat to our cybersecurity, the threat is real.

And when you are running a data-driven business, you simply can’t take things for granted.

That’s why data security is a hugely important and complex department in academia and business.

Here are some directions, or questions rather, that you can use as a guide on data security.

1. What’s the value of your data

2. Who has access to your data

3. Where your data is located

4. Who is protecting your data

5. How well your data is protected

These five questions and the answers to these will clear-up your vision towards data protection.

Thanks to Kate Carruthers for bringing the FIve Knows on Data Security of Mike Burgess to my attention.

Warning: Rant Ahead!

Have you ever wondered, why even after so many advancements in the field of business analytics, the dashboards are all the same old & boring charts & graphs & bars?

If so, then you probably have also asked yourself how to take our dashboards to the next level?

Pondering about this, I realised that the main thing the dashboards lack is action.

It’s just showing you the barren reports & summaries, without the underlying story & context. Most importantly, it’s not driving any action.

Here are a few ways to fix this:

- Plan for the actions you want to drive. Design the dashboards in such a way that would incorporate available options/triggers related to particular analysis or alert.

- Create high-focused dashboards for specific organisational processes or use cases. Too general dashboards make it difficult to gain actionable insights.

- Utilise data stories & long-form narratives for high-impact business cases and most important reports.

- Educate & guide the users on the use & benefits of enhanced reporting.

Instead of helping you to make quicker and better decisions, how is your dashboard slowing you down in business?

As analytics being widely implemented across all types of businesses, you are probably hearing about it quite a lot.

However, due to the linguistic complexities related to it, it’s easy to lose track & fall for some of the myths about the practice of business analytics.

Are you falling for one of those myths?

Business Analytics Automatically Solves Problems
Not exactly. Analytics brings out insights & possible directions for specific problems.

It’s you, who have to act upon those to solve the problems.

Data Analytics Is Too Expensive & Time-Consuming
Again, not necessarily.

You can always scale down solutions to your needs & specific business use case.

Artificial Intelligence Can Remove Bias
AI by default is not unbiased.

It depends upon the data you feed your algorithm to train your AI.

Data Analytics Causes Job Loss
On the contrary.

Data analytics & AI creates more avenues of revenues. So, it actually creates more jobs.

You Need to Gather All the Data in Your Business
Again, wrong. Data analytics is all about collecting the right data.

You have to collect data in a targeted & strategic way. The more data means more noise.

I believe there are more myths. Willing to chip-in?

Where do artificial intelligence and Machine Learning (AI/ML) fit into the larger scheme of business analytics?

It’s about evolution and progress.

How fast and how efficiently do you want your BI infrastructure to be and grow? I bet you want the best for your business, of course being within the budget limitations.

And, you would be happy to know that there’s a lot that you can do well within your monetary limitations.

AI-driven business analytics solutions that were previously only available to the multinationals are well within the reach of SMBs.

So, why should we be using AI/ML in conjunction with BI?

To deal with more data with more precision.

Analysts shouldn’t spend 80%-90% of their time buried into massive heaps of data to find out outliers or make sense out of it. Machines should do all the heavy lifting.

While analysts should be involved in making the meaning out of the alerts that machines offer them.

Thus, it solves the problem on both ends of the spectrum -- the data team and the business team.

Data teams get better and faster analytical power and the business teams get a more in-depth organisational story.

Are you using AI/ML in conjunction with business analytics?

What’s the difference between traditional business intelligence & embedded business intelligence?

In general terms, the difference between these two BI implementations is that the traditional BI is a standalone, separate application. Whereas, in case of embedded BI, the analytics & intelligence is embedded into whatever applications you already use for your day to day business processes.

It’s almost like having the intelligence always with you no matter which app you are using or at which business unit you are working on.

It means:

- Faster & easier access to intelligence

- You staff use intelligent decisioning right from the core app that they were already using

- Less time & resources spent on training & upskilling

- Improved productivity & revenue growth

My vision, however, is not at only the app level but at the mechanical level of your business operations.

With the help of IoT & edge analytics, every part of your business fully functioning & taking decisions on its own with analytics power embedded into it.

This almost seems sci-fi, but will soon be very much possible.

Would love to know your thoughts in the comments!

- Predictive analytics can determine & prevent possible fraud claims.

Self-service business intelligence (BI) is the way to go if you want to implement data analytics at an organisational level & foster a data-driven culture at your company.

However, it’s not without some challenges:

An increased number of users given access to data sources & reporting engines can lead to:

- Faulty input & output of data

- Superfluous data sets & reports causing performance hurdles for the system

- Increased threat to data security

Also, end-users often don’t care much about long-term data maintenance & governance.

So, how to stay away from these debacles & implement a successful self-service BI?

This train the trainer approach can help:

- Identify the superusers of the system, generally having prior expertise into analytics, cloud & the BI processes.

- Train the super users on every aspect of the technology from the early stages of adoption. Give them room to learn.

- Enable them to pass on the training to the end-users within the organisation. Support them throughout the process.

So, what do you think?

Can this tiered hands-on training approach solve the problems infesting self-service BI adoption?

[Inspired by an article published on TDWI]

While not every business will need this, Edge Analytics can be quite a useful tool for many businesses at the industrial level.

As time moves faster towards full 5G implementation & IoT devices are ever on the rise, edge analytics will become more popular.

As the name suggests, Edge analytics is data analytics being performed at the peripheral connected devices or nodes, instead of being sent back & analysed at the corporate data centres.

It improves response time significantly & saves bandwidth.

For example, imagine an oil field with all the heavy lifting & other industrial equipment functioning at full capacity.

A single malfunction may mean not only resource loss but also physical harm to workers.

What if all the equipment were connected & could use analytics algorithms on relevant sensor data themselves.

Simple predictive & descriptive algorithms can easily keep the machines working at their best & alert beforehand in case of malfunction.

Yes, it is already happening in many industries.

Can you see any use of edge analytics for your business?

If you are interested in learning more, listen to The Analytics Show episode featuring .

I built a digital marketplace for bicycles, I failed.

But I learned the importance of the marketplace and how to build the tool sets for the market.

I built North Hem for online furniture retailing and Airbnb for showrooms, I failed again.

But I learned how the consumers are buying and their purchase behaviour.

Very few people would ever make a billion-dollar from their first venture.

I didn’t expect to be one either.

Steve Jobs got kicked out of Apple, which may be considered as a failure at that time.

But what he started next became the cornerstone and foundation to rebuild Apple when he went back. That enabled him to build what Apple is today.

Learning from the failures of the digital marketplace, North Hem, and everything that I know about data analytics, I created the software as a service that’s helping hundreds of users around the world.

What did I do differently this time? I signed up 60 users before I wrote even a single line of code.

Also, combining the knowledge from all these different domains, we can now build better analytics tools.

So my question for you is what past failures are helping you succeed today?

We have been seeing a lot about how data science is changing the world.

How big data, AI, & automation are driving the 4th industrial revolution.

But how much of all these have actually reached individuals or even small businesses?

You might ask, what a grocery store or an individual will do with all these advanced technologies?

Let me tell a story.

I have a friend in Asia, who used to work as an office assistant while studying for a college degree. He’s very hardworking & frugal. Over the years, he saved a few thousand bucks from his salary.

“Why not invest in the stock market?” He thought.

So, he went on. Did a bit of manual analysis on his own & invested about half of his savings.

Guess what, it didn’t even take a week for his money to decrease by almost one-third.

Wouldn’t you say that there were faults in his analysis? Exactly that’s why analytics is for everybody.

And, it needs to be powered by subject matter expertise. Otherwise, blindly using the data will make you end up like him.

Now, that’s only one use case. Just think about it. You will also find at least one such event in your life when a better analytical power would have helped a lot.

5G technology has started to roll out throughout Australia.

We know that 5G is much better than the 4G network capabilities. But is it really the game-changer that many claim it to be?

I think so.

Just take this news for a start: Miners are working from home due to 5G enabled technology.

It’s the last job we thought could be done from home.

Now put it on scale and you get doctors performing remote surgeries.

So, what makes 5G capable of doing such feats?

- 5G can be 20 to 100 times faster than 4G. You can download full movies in just seconds.

- Latency is already low with 4G, but 5G will make it virtually zero.

This increased speed and decreased latency are what make this fifth-generation connectivity so much more powerful. This will make all the difference in the internet of things (IoT) revolution.

All the things that are connected will work seamlessly with each other making huge leaps in real-time analytics and automation.

On top of that, 4G can support only around 4,000 devices per square kilometre, whereas 5G will support around one million.

Are you excited to have 5G?

Warning: Rant ahead.

I know agile is tempting for good reasons. It’s fast and collaborative.

It really can be awesome if done right.

BUT

- I am not happy when a team just starts working on sprints with an almost zero idea of what the end product would look like.

- Developing random features on disparate bi-weekly sprints doesn’t qualify a project as agile.

- Starting iterations with a vague idea of the end product won’t make your project agile.

Just working on iterations without a clearly drawn path of the whole product development is a recipe for disaster.

So, be it agile or waterfall, it’s always important to keep the end goals in sight.

You should:

- Have a clear idea of the end results.

- Know how to achieve the end results.

- Break down the project with the end product in sight.

Let’s face it, releasing developments being not in sync with the ultimate goal will only hamper the whole project.

It would be the most non-agile thing to do.

Rant is over. Thank you for listening. Now, I would love to hear your rant about agile. Comment below or PM me. Coffee is on me!

Is data streaming like Netflix where you can see live data sets streaming by in front of you on a screen?

Nah! We all know that it is nothing like that.

Data streaming is the process that allows businesses to capture data from various sources right at the moment when they are created and generate real-time insights and decisioning.

- Data streaming lets you use the continuous flow of point of sale data, customer interaction data, social media data, IoT data, and others from thousands of data sources.

- You can see the real-time mobile app or website visitor usage and interaction.

- Show ads to customers based on their actual movement in various locations.

- Monitor performance of your industrial equipment or machinery and troubleshoot problems before service disruption.

- Automate your investment portfolio management by integrating real-time trading floor streaming data.

- Place just the right product in front of your eCommerce visitor based on their recent activities.

There are a lot of other usages of data streaming that will totally depend on your business needs.

Can you find any of your business needs being solved by real-time data analytics?

Can we implement geospatial analytics in business?

Some forms of analytics are linked to location data by nature.

For example, analytics involving census data or socio-economic metrics.

However, with the advancement of technology, we can collect geo-referenced data from multiple sources, i.e. mobile devices, social media, and others, for any event that concerns our business.

So, a geospatial approach to analytics can benefit many avenues of business.

Our minds do not see and understand things in terms of tables, rows, and columns. We need visual stories based on data for permanent and insightful perception.

Geospatial analytics helps us do exactly that!

- It gives context to our data stories by relating with time and place.

- We can create maps around an event of interest and observe where and how the changes occur.

- Maps make it easier to uncover patterns concerning distance, proximity, and other correlations.

- Better analyse historical shifts to understand the present and predict the future.

- Streamline location-based decision making, trend forecasting, and targeted solutions.

What other ways can you use geospatial analytics for your business?

You might have heard your developer friends talk about database normalisation & wondered how to normalise data?

Isn’t it normal already?

As part of my general knowledge sharing activity, let me explain why they were talking about normalising the database.

Suppose you have a spreadsheet of data containing information of all the salespeople of your organization.

The sheet also contains columns about which office they are located, their clients, office phone number & other related data.

Now, if you store all of it in a single table, you will face multiple problems.

When changing an office location, you will have to change all the rows containing salespeople working at that office. The same is true for any kind of changes, such as phone numbers.

One change will impact the whole database. It will take a lot of time to individually incorporate the changes throughout the table.

Here, comes database normalisation!

It is a database design technique that breaks down your database into smaller independent tables and then links them together with e few lines of code.

As a result, you can easily change, add, or remove any single data input without having to make changes all through the database.

Isn’t it cool?

What is a data catalogue?

Data cataloguing is one of the major processes for storing and managing your data in the most efficient way.

Though often termed as a metadata management tool, a data catalogue goes beyond just technical metadata attributes and incorporates many more data characteristics concerning practical use cases.

For example:

Metadata for a data set might contain only the names of the tables, columns, and rows and the types of data they contain.

However, a data catalogue will move ahead into denoting other attributes like business use cases (i.e. sales or HR), trust score, source, compliance sensitivity, and many others.

Why having data catalogues essential for your analytics operations?

- Data cataloguing allows you to find, access and use stored data fast and easy.
- You get to know exactly where you will get the data that you need.
- Each of the data sets gives you a clear picture of its quality, use cases, efficacy, and lineage.
- Any user can annotate the data sets with significant details for future use cases.
- Overall significant ROI from your data and analytics efforts.

What other benefits of data catalogues have you experienced?

Warning: Rant ahead!

Yes, the organiser apps like Jira or Trello are great for keeping things into perspective & routine.

BUT

- Having our project running JIRA with a 2 weeks sprint does not automatically qualify the project for agile methodology.

- Having our project running without any clear idea of the end goals for the customers is really not a great way to say we are running a project using agile methodology.

- Having our project with daily standup with repeated messages does not make it agile but rather, it’s wasting time.

Just applying all of these mechanics like the above, does not guarantee that the project will succeed.

Let’s face it. Agile or not, it’s always important to:

- Break down our project into smaller components to tackle

- Have a clear idea of how the end solution should be

- Optimise the time of your project resources. Apart from their skill sets, we are paying for their time to develop a solution.

So, without all these things, we can’t claim that we are agile, and according to the myth, agile will double the success rate of our project.

Cloud adoption.

Maybe you have done it already or planning to do it very soon.

But no matter what, it is soon going to be a must for every business running on technology.

So, I thought of checking out what are your favourite approaches to cloud migration?

For your reference, these are the major approaches for cloud migration:

Rehost: You choose to lift and shift your analytics applications on cloud hardware environments.

Refactor: You re-architect and modify your analytics application for a cloud platform environment.

Rebuild: You totally abandon your existing analytics applications and rebuild them as per your cloud environment provider’s platform and infrastructure.

Replace: You abandon your analytics applications for readily available Software as a Service (SaaS) cloud environment.

Effective business analytics should take all the forces involved in business operations into consideration.

Multivariate statistical analysis makes it easier for business to do exactly that!

There are four common techniques for doing multivariate statistical analysis:

- Multiple regression

It lets you map the influence of multiple variables on one outcome, such as effects on sales of all your market dynamics.

- Factor Analysis

Through factor analysis, you can uncover patterns among various factors, like age, wealth, location, and cluster highly interrelated variables in terms of customer behaviour so you know what to prioritise.

- Path Analysis

Path analysis shows correlations among multiple variables using graphs or path diagrams so you get a graphical view of the relationships among data elements.

- Multiple Analysis of Variance

It lets you study the effects of multiple grouping factors on two or more variables. For example, you can group your employees depending on the training received and analyse the effects on various performance indicators to find out the efficacy of the training.

How are you using statistical analysis in driving business outcome?

One of the major reasons behind bad performing machine learning models is overfitting or underfitting of data.

While training an ML model, we feed it with a set of model data from which it gradually starts to learn how to generalise and predict using new unknown data.

Overfitting occurs when the model starts to learn from the data too well to be able to create any generalised understanding.

Like any other data sets, the training data is also likely to contain noise and random fluctuations.

So, if an algorithm or model starts to learn the data too much that means it also makes the fluctuations a part of its learning curve that incapacitates it from being able to make any generalization.

Or even if it becomes able to make a decision, it takes into consideration the noise of the training data. Hence, the predictions are faulty.

Underfitting is the opposite.

When the training data simply becomes insufficient or not enough to create any generalised learning for the model.

The model simply won’t be able to make any decisions on new unknown inputs.

How would such fitting challenges of the analytics model impact the business outcome at your organisations?

Keeping your data in perfect shape is of the utmost importance when it comes to business analytics.

How can you improve data integrity and quality?

- Build a Data-Driven Culture

The data-driven mindset of your staff will ensure that they are respectful towards data processes. This means less human errors in your management reports and dealings with customer data.

- Provide Sufficient Training

As automation of all the parts of data sourcing and mining is not yet possible, so human errors are still one of the predominant reasons for bad data. Comprehensive employee training is essential, especially because the data is used in dealing with customers.

- Automation

Automatic data collection and analytics processes make your whole data operation consistent and reduce human error.

- Constantly Monitor and Update

You have to keep updating the data validation, cleaning, and maintenance processes to be on top of the industry trends.

- Consistent Definition and Sources

Clear and consistent data definitions and unified data sources enhance data integrity. Also, make the data analytical processes easier to carry out for better decisions.

What other steps do you take?

We often tend to use the terms business analytics and business analysis interchangeably.

Although they complement each other, these two terms are quite different.

Yes, both of them are there to solve business problems and drive growth. However, the tools, strategies, approaches, and skill set required are different.

- Business analysis is focused on studying organisational and enterprise architecture using tools like SWOT analysis and PESTLE analysis, while business analytics depends on data and statistical models to uncover deeper insights that are not otherwise visible to naked eye.

- Business analysis is done to solve current business problems, while analytics can predict future states or optimise your business operations.

- Analysis mostly understands the business processes and functions, whereas, analytics impact forecasting and decision making.

- For doing business analysis you will need business knowledge and industry insights, but for analytics, you will need programming skills, statistics and mathematical skills along with business knowledge.

Despite their inherent differences, these two go hand in hand to improve business.

Can you think of any other similarities and differences?

Whether it is facial recognition or autonomous cars, we often tend to think that artificial intelligence (AI) is some sort of technological magic that works on its own.

In reality, all that an AI is capable of doing is not possible at all without human inputs.

Let’s look at a comparatively simpler AI model first.

Imagine, you are using an image recognition AI that can detect and tell you the name of plants in front of you by using your phone camera.

How did that app come to know that information in the first place?

There are a lot of work hours of hard-working humans behind the machinery.

Somewhere, a team of professionals called data labellers was:

- Collecting all the images of plants and flowers
- Tagging them with names manually
- Feeding the labelled data into the AI models
- Gradually training the model to spot and detect those plants in real-time.

So, how many plants are there in the world? And how many years will it take you to label all of those?

Now, put things into a larger scale.

Think of training a self-driving car’s AI, how many dimensions of data labelling would that require?

Watch the video to get a real view of the human play in AI!

How can you know the effects of your actions even before performing them?

Well, you cannot know the future impact of all your actions beforehand, but you certainly can get a somewhat realistic prediction of your business actions that have related historical data to infer upon.

The tools you have to use is called what-if analytics, also known as the sensitivity analysis.

It is statistical modelling that lets you play with different variables to determine all the possible outcomes.

With what-if analysis, you can make the decision-making process much easier and accurate.

For example:

Suppose, you are going for cloud adoption of your business analytics processes and are now evaluating various segments of your workload to determine which ones you should begin moving to the cloud.

Before you start to move, you need to evaluate different attributes to find out the most suitable parts of your workload based on value, efforts, or other considerations.

With a what-if model based on your options and attributes, you figure out the most suitable workloads to move to clouds.

How would what-if analysis improve the quality of your business decision-making?

Today’s topic is random forest algorithms.

Random forest is a very effective and popular model for training machine learning algorithms.

By using random forest models, your algorithms can perform many useful tasks involving classification, categorization, and prediction.

Just like any normal forest, random forests also consist of trees.

These trees are called the decision trees because each tree in the forest has to make a decision. It is a piece of the algorithm that makes the decision based on a feature or criterion.

For example, if you take a group of students and want to categorize them as A+ and B+ students, a single decision tree can make the categorization based on their scores.

But when the decisions you have to take involve many other features, instead of just the grades of the students, you will need many more trees focusing on unrelated features or variables.

And these trees, in turn, will make up the random forest model as a whole, that will be able to make the decisions for you based on numerous factors that you want to consider.

Something wonderful, isn’t it?

What do you do with raw data?

You transform it into a usable format to carry out analytics.

And, this process of transforming raw data into various formats that can be used for analytical purposes is called data wrangling or data munging.

How can you wrangle the data?

- First, you need to understand what data you need for answering the questions.

- You have to discover and understand the data deeply. What is it about? Can this be used to answer my questions?

- Based on your understanding of your data, business and system, you need to deploy methods of structuring the data according to the analytical model you are going to implement.

- Now you have to weed out fluctuations, noise, and outliers out of your structured data sets.

- In the next step, you have to determine what other data can you add to your data set to further augment its quality.

- Yet another step named data validation is required for further ensuring that all of your data elements are in line with your defined attributes and categories.

- Finally, you are all set to publish your data to the data analysts to create all those beautiful reports.

Is your data a single source of truth?

Linear regression is one of the most used statistical modelings in data analytics.

But why are we talking about such a simple thing all of sudden? Because it is often the simplest of solutions that skips our attention.

Linear regression helps us to chart the linear correlations between two variables.

It is often represented by a slanting line on the Cartesian coordinate graph - the one with the X and Y axes.

The line shows how the value of one variable is affecting the outcome of the other through a linear representation.

Take for example, if you want to find out how your pricing changes over the years have affected the number of sales, you can easily do that with linear regression modeling.

Just put the price and sales variable along the axes of X and Y and see the magic.

With it, you can also efficiently predict how any future pricing change will affect the market. Smart, isn’t it?

You can also predict the effect of multiple variables on a single outcome using linear regression, which is called multiple regression. Maybe we will discuss this in a future post.

Enterprise business analytics is so heavily reliant on massive computing power and storage that cloud can certainly be a lifesaver.

But before you jump on the bandwagon, what are the issues should you be mindful of?

- Consider multi-cloud or hybrid cloud strategy.

- Prioritize apps and operations that you can safely migrate to cloud without any impact on daily business.

- Involve all the stakeholders in the process of cloud strategy development and execution so that all needs and goals are covered.

- Provide necessary training and upskilling to staff members on the upcoming changes.

- Consider the security and licensing details of the vendors you chose.

- Have clearly laid out terms and conditions with the vendors so that you face no troubles retaining and transferring your data to other vendors if needs arise.

- Instead of ad hoc piecemeal cloud adoption, have an overall strategy and adhere to it so that you have the full picture of cost and ROI.

- Always keep the risks that you might face and keep backup plans active while migrating critical business operations so that your business performance remains as usual.

What other factors should businesses be concerned about?

ETL is an essential operation for running any data and analytical process. It stands for Extract, Transform, and Load.

- Extract is used to collect data from multiple sources as needed.

- Transform means manipulating the data for making it usable. Calculations, validations, concatenation, formatting, and others take place during the transformation process.

- Load means putting this data on analytical platforms like data warehouses for analysis.

ETL is used to:

- Consolidate data into data warehouses from disparate sources.

- Migrate data from one database, data mart, or data warehouses to another.

- Convert databases from one format to another.

Another alternative but similar process called ELT is further used for more streamlining of data into databases.

ELT stands for extract, load, and then, transform. The foundation idea of ELT, instead of ETL, is to take advantage of the power of cloud computing. Thus, you load the data into the server and transform in the cloud.

For BI solutions, ETL and ELT are indispensable for making sense of so much incoming data from so many sources.

Without a proper data warehouse in place, can your analytics perform?

Supervised machine learning simply means you are feeding your machine learning algorithms with an already labeled and tagged set of data so that it gradually becomes trained in analysing and predicting with unknown data sets.

For example:

If you train your algorithm with all of your marketing spending and corresponding sales data over the period of a few years, it will gradually become able to predict what will be the outcome of spending on sales in the next few years.

However, as the data sets become more complex in terms of more variables and not so direct outcomes, the process becomes a bit tenuous.

The discipline of Information Architecture has applications in multiple fields of information technology.

From simple websites to enterprise BI solutions everything needs information architecture.

We all are probably aware of quantitative and qualitative analytics. But a little brush up is always a good idea for staying ahead.

Quantitative analytics is the aspect of data analytics that deals with hard numbers.

Anything that you can put a numerical label on can be taken under the purview of quantitative analytics.

For example:

- Cost and profit analysis that deals with the real numbers of your expenditure and profits.

- Website traffic and conversion rates from the number of conversions and site visitors.

On the other hand, qualitative analytics comes into play when we don’t have any hard number related to a variable that we want to analyse.

Such as:

- Why a product is favored over the other

- What features of your product are liked by customers and why

- What is the social media sentiment of your target audience

All this information, vital for a business, can not be labeled with a numerical digit, but that doesn’t mean that they should be out of our data analytical apparatus.

You can get to analyse these qualitative data with the help of qualitative analytics methods.

The importance of audience targeting for marketing initiatives can not be stressed further.

One of the common audience targeting techniques so far have been demographic analytics, with which you can segment and target your audience by age, gender, income groups, ethnicity, and other such variables.

But this method has an inherent flaw in it that it presumes all the members of a demographic group would somehow have similar characteristics and interests.

Which can be far from what is observed in the real world.

That’s where behavioral analytics come into play.

Though a bit difficult to carry out than the demographic analytics, the benefits of behavioral analytics are greater when it comes to marketing effectiveness.

Through behavioral analytics, you get to group your target audience based on their actual interests and characteristics which allow you to:

- Craft more relevant messages for your audience
- Enhance interactions with customers
- Create better customer experience
- Form improved brand loyalty
- Increase conversions

We often use the terms database and data warehouse interchangeably.

But are they really the same thing?

Moreover, what on earth is a data lake?

Simply put:

- A database is a data storage unit where all the data is structured and ready to be analysed by the user.

- Data warehousing is a process for collecting and managing data from varied sources. It’s typically used to connect and analyze business data from heterogeneous sources. It’s the core of the BI system for data analysis and reporting.

- Data lakes are completely different kinds of storage units specifically used for very large amounts of unstructured and structured raw data.

For example:

Suppose, you are keeping the records of all your employees in a spreadsheet or table, it can be called a simple database structure.

One the other hand, a data warehouse is where all of the data sources from all the departments, i.e. HR, sales, marketing, are integrated, stored, & accessed for analysis.

And in a data lake, you will keep all other data that are not structured for analysis yet, i.e., social media texts, customer query texts, machine logs, IoT sensor data, videos, docs, and others.

In my effort to bring to you data & analytics insights on a regular basis, today we are going to have a look at an important visual analytics tool: the scatter plot.

Scatter plot or scatter diagram occupies a very useful place within the arena of visual analytics.

It clusters your data points on a chart over the axes of X and Y - the two variables that you want to analyse.

You can use additional codifying techniques of color or size of the clusters to factor in the third variable.

With scatter plot visualisation technique, you can easily observe the correlation among two to three variables - how each of the variables or factors influences each other?

For example:

1. You can use scatter plot to determine how marketing expenditure correlates with new customer acquisition in each quarter of the year.

2. How the cost of a product relates to its being sold.

3. Which type of ads are bringing better results in what time of the day and which targeted areas.

4. For audience targeting, you can find out the relation between your targeted demographic and their location.

The list can go on! Let me know how have you used scatter plot so far?

What is descriptive analytics?

It is the use of data and analytics to make sense of what has transpired.

Suppose, you witness a sudden surge in customer query and you have no clue what happened.

You can take help from descriptive business analytics to figure out exactly what caused the spike in customer activity.

You may make use of text analysis of all the customer queries to find out the major reasons for queries.

You may also use historical data to compare customer activities over the years.

Well, it is a very simplistic example of the use of descriptive analytics.

Descriptive analytical techniques can be applied to explain whatever concerns you might have.

It is the most common analytical function - to describe events using data.

It can also be used to-

- Create overviews of business activities over a period, be it sales, marketing campaigns, production, or management.

- Making sense of social media activities surrounding your brand.

- Explaining any business trends in the making.

- Explaining customer behavior over a period of time or about a certain product or service.

And much more.

What are your stories of using descriptive analytics?

What is predictive analytics?

It is one of the most common data analytical approaches that involves predicting future events by analysing the current and historical data.

In the case of predictive analysis, statistics, and modeling are based on the goals of predicting a specific outcome. The methods of collecting, mining, and storing data remains the same.

What are the business outcomes can you predict with data and analytics?

- Customer behavior at a future point of time based on historical data. It allows you to better launch, market, sell, and cross-sell your products and services.

- Demand for a specific product at any specific time. You will know what to sell, when to sell, and sell to whom.

- Risk associated with any business operations. What are the probable risks lie ahead for your business and what can be done to minimise them?

- Outcomes and opportunities for further business growth.

- What resources should be deployed at which time for maximum efficacy?

These are just to name a few of the use case scenarios of predictive business analytics.

Have you utilised predictive analytics for your business yet?

Do you need a new data scientist or an engineer for your business analytics team?

It is one of the areas where businesses could often commit mistakes.

We often tend to think that data scientists and data engineers are the same.

To figure out which professionals you currently need, ask these 2 questions.

1. Do you lack enough people who can code and create new data warehouses, data hubs, modeling, and analytical platforms for you?

2. Do you lack the skills needed to effectively figure out what kind of statistical tools and new mathematical models are required for the target analysis from the available data sources?

If you said yes to the first question, you need data engineers.

If you said yes to the second one, you need a data scientist.

If you said yes to both, you need both of them.

On the other hand, if you have all the necessary data, required models, and a robust architecture already at hand, but finding it difficult to analyse and report effectively, you need more data analysts.

Keeping this basic checklist in mind will keep you away from unnecessary and mismatched hires and will save you from a lot of headaches.
